docs.snippet: Frank Schiffman, who in 1934 was the co-founder of Harlem's Apollo Theater, died yesterday at his home in Surfside. He was 80 years old. The Apollo had been a burlesque theater when Mr. Schiffman, who already owned several theaters in Harlem, boug...
docs.lead_paragraph: Frank Schiffman, who in 1934 was the co-founder of Harlem's Apollo Theater, died yesterday at his home in Surfside. He was 80 years old. The Apollo had been a burlesque theater when Mr. Schiffman, who already owned several theaters in Harlem, bought it in 1934 with Leo Brecher.

headline.main: Frank Schiffman, Co-Founder Of Harlem's Apollo, Dies at 80

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: A strong business performance for 1974 is widely expected by business and industrial leaders, a survey by The New York Times of dozens of leading companies disclosed, although the energy crisis and continuing questions over the Nixon Administratio...
docs.lead_paragraph: A strong business performance for 1974 is widely expected by business and industrial leaders, a survey by The New York Times of dozens of leading companies disclosed, although the energy crisis and continuing questions over the Nixon Administration's economic controls program caused much uncertainty in the forecasting.
docs.abstract: NY Times survey of dozens of leading cos discloses that most expect strong business performance for '74 despite fuel crisis (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: 3:30 P.M. [2] SUPER BOWL. The Miami Dolphins play the Minnesota Vikings with Ray Scott, Pat Summerall and Bart Starr as commentators. 3:30 [4] A YEAR APART. Nineteen NBC News correspondents discuss the important events of 1973 with John Chancellor, David Brinkley, Frank McGee and Edwin Newman.

headline.main: Television This Week; OF SPECIAL INTEREST

docs.snippet: Tomorrow will be Super Bowl day at last. After two weeks of impatient waiting, the Miami Dolphins and Minnesota Vikings will settle the championship of the National Football League on the synthetic turf of Rice Stadium before a crowd of 71,882, wi...
docs.lead_paragraph: Tomorrow will be Super Bowl day at last. After two weeks of impatient waiting, the Miami Dolphins and Minnesota Vikings will settle the championship of the National Football League on the synthetic turf of Rice Stadium before a crowd of 71,882, with 80 million expected to watch on television in the United States, Canada, Venezuela and Mexico.

headline.main: Dolphins Choice Over Vikings In Today's Super Showdown; How Super Bowl Rivals Match Up

byline.original: Special to The New York Times
